meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Jeopardy Archive Stephanie Jass Roger Craig Vijay Balse Final clue response question answer Daily Double

meta.name: description
meta.content: An archive of clues and players for Jeopardy! show #6807.

div.div: Battle of the Decades: The 2000s game 2.

td.p: Stephanie Jass, a history professor from Milan, Michigan
Roger Craig, a data scientist from Brooklyn, New York
Vijay Balse, a chemical engineer consulting in renewable energy from Chatham, New Jersey

tr.td: THE "AUGHT"S
AMERICAN NOVELISTS
BRAND NAMES
CABLE NETWORKS
INVENTORS & INVENTIONS
I STAND BEFORE THE COUNTRY
(Alex: You have to complete the country's two-word name.)

tr.td: Vijay
Roger
Stephanie
KING JAMES BIBLE QUOTES
HISTORIC OBJECTS
WORLD NEWSPAPERS

div.onmouseout: toggle('clue_DJ_6_1', 'clue_DJ_6_1_stuck', '(Kelly of the Clue Crew gives us a clue about the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland.) CERN really is the coolest place on Earth; prior to operation, one-eighth of the LHC was cooled with superfluid helium to -271 degrees Celsius, a few degrees above this term for the lowest temperature possible')

a.title: Suggest a correction for this clue

tr.td: (Kelly of the Clue Crew gives us a clue about the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland.) CERN really is the coolest place on Earth; prior to operation, one-eighth of the LHC was cooled with superfluid helium to -271 degrees Celsius, a few degrees above this term for the lowest temperature possible

div.onmouseout: toggle('clue_DJ_6_2', 'clue_DJ_6_2_stuck', '(Kelly of the Clue Crew comes to us from the halls of CERN in Geneva, Switzerland.) The offices of this corridor were those of CERN computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee, who wanted to connect hypertext to the internet in an effort to easily relay information, thereby creating this service that is now practically synonomous with the internet.')

a.title: Suggest a correction for this clue

tr.td: (Kelly of the Clue Crew comes to us from the halls of CERN in Geneva, Switzerland.) The offices of this corridor were those of CERN computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee, who wanted to connect hypertext to the internet in an effort to easily relay information, thereby creating this service that is now practically synonomous with the internet.

body.div: The J! Archive is created by fans, for fans. The Jeopardy! game show and all elements thereof, including but not limited to copyright and trademark thereto, are the property of Jeopardy Productions, Inc. and are protected under law. This website is not affiliated with, sponsored by, or operated by Jeopardy Productions, Inc. Join the discussion at JBoard.tv.
